Underlying Patterns and Repeating Questions in FPSC English Exams (2005--2009) Note: All papers follow a 3-hour format with 100 marks (except 2009, split into MCQs and subjective sections).
1. Précis Writing Pattern: Write a précis of a ~150--200 word passage and suggest a suitable title (20+5 marks).
2007: Impact of literature on human personality. 2008: Organizational objectives and efficiency. 2009: Art's role in emotion vs. morality (Plato/Tolstoi).
2. Comprehension Questions Pattern: Answer short analytical questions (3--8 marks each) based on a literary or critical passage.
Focus on interpretation, vocabulary, and author's intent. Repeating Skills Tested: Main idea extraction (e.g., "What kind of education does the writer favor?" -- 2007).
Contextual meaning of phrases (e.g., "sour-grapeism" -- 2006). Tone and purpose (e.g., "Why did the writer's father study the skies?"
3. Essay/Comprehensive Note (250--300 words) Pattern: Philosophical, moral, or societal themes with a choice of 5 topics.
2007: "Where ignorance is bliss, it is folly to be wise." Human Behavior & Society: 2005: "Democracy fosters mediocrity."
2008: "Life without philosophy is like a ship without a rudder." Art and Creativity: 2006: "A pen becomes a clarion."
2009: "Protecting freedom of expression not lies." Proverbs/Idioms: 2005: "Each man is the architect of his own destiny."
2008: "The child is father of the man." 4. Vocabulary Pattern: Synonyms/Antonyms: Match words like anathema, torpor, sequester
5. Grammar Pattern: Direct/Indirect Speech: Convert sentences (e.g., "Ali said, 'I must go to Lahore'" -- 2005).
Sentence Correction: Fix errors in syntax, prepositions, or comparisons (e.g., "Your writing is inferior than him" → to -- 2008).
Common Errors Tested: Incorrect comparisons (greater than twenty years ago → greater than those twenty years ago).
Dangling modifiers (Having entered his house, the door was shut). 6. Idioms and Phrases Pattern:
Use idioms in sentences (e.g., salt something away, wear the pants in the family -- 2005--2009). Repeating Idioms:
Blow one's top (2008), Turncoat (2009), Letter perfect (2005). Year-Specific Observations 2005: Emphasis on psychology (Q1) and meteorological analogies (Q2).
2006: Critiques of modern education vs. classical philosophy (Q2). 2007: Focus on industrialization and cultural erosion (Q3).
2008: Themes of organizational efficiency and spiritual revival (Q2). 2009: Debate on art's moral impact (Q2) and Western lifestyle critiques (Q4).
Build Vocabulary: Focus on synonyms/antonyms and confusing word pairs. Analyze Philosophical Topics: Prepare arguments for common themes like ignorance, democracy, and art.
Grammar Drills: Prioritize direct/indirect speech and common syntax errors. Idioms Practice: Learn 10--15 idioms yearly and their contextual usage.
Underlying Patterns and Repeating Questions in FPSC English Exams (2010--2014) Note: All papers follow a 3-hour format with 100 marks (split into MCQs and subjective sections).
1. Précis Writing Pattern: Write a précis of a ~150--200 word passage and suggest a suitable title (20--25 marks).
Themes include psychology, social issues, culture, education, and governance. Repeating Themes: 2010: Envy and its psychological impact.
2011: Psychological causes of unhappiness. 2012: Population control and social stratification. 2013: Culture and social structure.
2014: Moral education and intelligence. 2. Comprehension Questions Pattern: Answer analytical questions (4--5 marks each) based on historical, philosophical, or critical passages.
Repeating Skills Tested: Main idea extraction (e.g., "Why did Galileo recant?" -- 2010). Contextual meaning (e.g., "sour-grapeism" -- 2010).
Proverbs: 2010: "When flatterers get together, the devil goes to dinner." 2011: "Child is the father of man."
2013: "Revolution versus Evolution." Societal Issues: 2012: "Self done is Well done." 2014: "Actions speak louder than words."
Human Behavior: 2011: "Love is a beautiful but baleful god." 2013: "Beneath every cloud there is always a silver lining."
Pairs of Words: Differentiate homophones (e.g., adverse/averse, species/specie). Repeating Words: Synonyms: Void (2010), Chronicle (2011), Bristle (2013).
Antonyms: Vulgar (2010), Hypocrisy (2011), Inclement (2013). 5. Grammar Pattern: Direct/Indirect Speech: Convert sentences (e.g., "He said, 'My son is coming today'" -- 2010).
Sentence Correction: Fix errors in syntax, prepositions, or comparisons (e.g., "Fear from God" → of -- 2012).
Common Errors Tested: Incorrect comparisons (climate of Pakistan vs. England -- 2010). Tense inconsistencies (He has come yesterday -- 2012).
6. Idioms and Phrases Pattern: Use idioms in sentences (e.g., Yeoman's service, A swan song -- 2010--2014).
Repeating Idioms: Discretion is the better part of valour (2010). A wet blanket (2011). Wool gathering (2012).
2011: Focus on knowledge vs. understanding and human unhappiness. 2012: Themes of population control and fear of death.
2013: Analysis of Confucian ethics and cultural evolution. 2014: Comparative study of revolutions and moral education.
Key Takeaways for Preparation Master Précis Writing: Practice summarizing dense texts on psychology, society, and culture.
Build Vocabulary: Focus on synonyms/antonyms and confusing word pairs (e.g., adverse/averse). Analyze Historical Passages: Prepare for comparative questions (e.g., American vs. French Revolution).
Grammar Drills: Prioritize direct/indirect speech and common syntax errors. Idioms Practice: Memorize 10--15 idioms yearly (e.g., To let the grass grow under one's feet -- 2014)
Underlying Patterns and Repeating Questions in Federal Government BS-17 English Exams (2015--2019) 1. Précis Writing (Q.2 in All Years)
Pattern: Write a précis of ~120--130 words and suggest a title. Topics: Philosophical/social issues (war, education, civilization), travel experiences, climate effects.
Recurring Themes: 2015: War as a catalyst for civilization's collapse. 2016: Travelogue to Cherokee, Oklahoma.
2017: Critique of overactivity vs. the value of "laziness." 2018: Impact of climate on human productivity.
2019: Modern education theories. 2. Comprehension (Q.3 in All Years) Pattern: Answer analytical questions (meanings, author's intent, implications).
Passages focus on social criticism, human behavior, or literary excerpts. Recurring Question Types: Phrase Meanings (e.g., "nobler hypothesis," "malignity of war").
Author's Justification (e.g., Why trust the scientific method? Why do resolutions fail?). Critical Analysis (e.g., "Is beauty an ornament?").
Textual Evidence (e.g., "How does the crowd behave?" in 2019's sci-fi passage). 3. Grammar & Vocabulary
a. Sentence Correction (Q.4/Q.6 in All Years) Pattern: Correct 5 out of 8 sentences with errors in:
Parallel structure (e.g., "I always have and always shall be your friend"). Prepositions (e.g., "arrive at our destination").
Pattern: Match word pairs (e.g., LION : ROAR → SNAKE : SLITHER). Common themes: Profession-traits (e.g., SURGEON : DEXTEROUS), cause-effect (e.g., FEARFUL : COWER).
c. Word Pairs (Q.5b/Q.6a in All Years) Pattern: Differentiate homophones or similar-sounding words (e.g., adverse vs. averse, born vs. borne).
d. Phrase Usage (Q.5a/Q.6b in All Years) Pattern: Use idioms/phrases in sentences (e.g., "beard the lion in his den," "place in the sun").
Common phrases: Murphy's Law, smash hit, spirit away. 4. Translation (Q.7 in 2016, 2018, 2019) Pattern:
Translate Urdu paragraphs into English, preserving figurative/idiomatic expressions. Themes: Cultural heritage, historical cities (e.g., Lahore in 2018), moral lessons.
5. Dialogue Conversion (2016, 2018) Pattern: Convert direct ↔ indirect speech (e.g., 2016's dialogue between Helen and Mr. West).
6. Essay Writing (2015 Only) Pattern (2015 Q.4): Write 250--300 words on topics like "Education for life, not livelihood" or "Human nature in adversity."
Yearly Shifts 2015: Emphasis on essays and literary analysis. 2016--2019: Shift toward grammar drills (sentence correction, prepositions) and translation.
Précis Practice: Focus on condensing philosophical/social arguments. Comprehension Skills: Analyze tone, intent, and textual evidence.
Example (2020): "don't begin with a hackneyed phrase like I was delighted..." → Add punctuation for clarity.
Pattern: Focus on nuanced prepositions (on, in, by, for) and complex punctuation in long sentences.
Task: Use word pairs in sentences to illustrate meanings. Examples: 2020: Nip in the bud vs. Break the ice.
